programme.title: Wildlife
Wildlife : une saison ardente
programme.desc:
Wildlife: Directed by Paul Dano. With Ed Oxenbould, Jake Gyllenhaal, Carey Mulligan, Travis W Bruyer. A teenage boy must deal with his mother's complicated response after his father temporarily abandons them to take a menial and dangerous job." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt5929754/","name":"Wildlife","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOTNlZWY2ZGQtY2U1ZS00Mjc5LWExNjgtM2Q4YzQyYTlmNjZhXkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyODY3Nzc0OTk@._V1_.jpg","description":"A teenage boy must deal with his mother's complicated response after his father temporarily abandons them to take a menial and dangerous job.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt5929754/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Bertaut"},"dateCreated":"2018-11-16","inLanguage":"English","name":"Old-fashioned filmmaking with a progressive theme","reviewBody":"The directorial debut of actor Paul Dano, Wildlife is based on the 1990 novel by Richard Ford, and is written for the screen by Dano and his girlfriend Zoe Kazan. Looking at the implosion of a family from the perspective of a 14-year-old member of said family, the film is thematically similar to Revolutionary Road (2008) and Blue Valentine (2010), and aesthetically similar to the Texas scenes in The Tree of Life (2011) (the period detail drips off the screen, whilst the use of a child as the focaliser colours much of what's depicted). And although Wildlife is a piece of remarkably nostalgic filmmaking, at the same time, it tells somewhat of a progressive story, demonstrating the uncertainty with which second-wave feminism manifested itself at a grassroots level prior to really taking off in 1963. Although it's essentially a character study, the film also suggests the 1950s-style clean-cut, neatly trimmed, rigidly defined way of life, built around the perfect nuclear family wherein a wife must be subservient to her husband, is about to become a thing of the past.

Set in Great Falls, Montana in 1960, the film tells the story of the peripatetic Brinson family; father Jerry (Jake Gyllenhaal), mother Jeannette (Carey Mulligan), and 14-year-old son Joe (Ed Oxenbould). When Jerry loses his job and takes off in a misguided attempt to reaffirm his masculinity by fighting a forest fire, something is awoken in Jeanette, who, for the first time, allows herself to admit she has become deeply unhappy, and overnight, her behaviour changes dramatically, as she rebels against her domesticity. Determined to forge a new identity, she is adamant she won't become one of the "standing dead" (the term used for trees that survive a forest fire).

Importantly, the film is set three years prior to Betty Friedan's ground-breaking The Feminine Mystique (1963), which redefined the parameters of all gender-based topics, depicting a society in which women were no longer content to do their husband's bidding and raise children. Initially, Jeanette is depicted as a quintessential 1950s wife and mother, almost to the point of cliché; she cooks, cleans, washes the clothes, does the dishes, sees that Joe attend to his homework, and when Jerry loses his job, it is Jeanette who goes out looking for work for both of them. She knows that her (unspoken and unacknowledged) role in this patriarchal society is to hold the family together, but it's a role that is nothing like she thought it would be when she was younger. Although she and Jerry seem to love one another, or they certainly used to, she clearly feels trapped by her domestic situation.

That her transformation happens so quickly is the key point; when she goes to bed, she's a wife and mother, trapped in her domestic environment, but when she wakes the next morning, she realises that she has an opportunity to escape, perhaps the best opportunity she will ever get. This has been building up for years, but she has gotten so used to feeling lost that when she gets a chance to change things, she doesn't even recognise it as such, at least not at first. Once she does, however, Jeanette makes a conscious decision to stop performing the role delegated by men. As much of the female population of the western hemisphere would be asking over the next ten or so years, Jeanette wants to know, "is this all there is?" She wants more than simply getting through the day. In this sense, she recalls Nora Helmer from Henrik Ibsen's A Doll's House (1879), or any number of Tennessee Williams heroines - a woman who wakes up to find she has become deeply unhappy despite attaining everything she once wanted, and who sets out to do whatever it takes to alter her course.

That all is not well in the Brinson household is hinted at in the opening scene, where Jerry and Jeanette have a couple of inconsequential but noticeable disagreements over dinner (such as whether Joe should continue pursuing football). This scene establishes an assuredness and subtlety-of-hand that lasts for the entire film, with Dano's directorial work proving unexpectedly sophisticated. For example, something he does several times is have characters walk off-screen to speak, whilst keeping the camera trained on Joe as he tries to listen, with the dialogue barely perceptible from just off the edge of the frame. As well as being an excellent use of off-screen space, something you don't see too often, this technique ties us rigidly to Joe's POV early on, inculcating us into his worldview. Another very nice piece of direction is an early montage cutting between Jeanette riding her bike, Jerry driving the car, and Joe riding the bus, in which each character is facing a different direction, each in isolation from the other two. It's basic cinematic shorthand, showing instead of telling, but it's very well done. Equally impressive is the penultimate scene, where Dano uses the windows of the Brinson house to block the characters in such a way as to suggest both their inner emotions, and the prevailing theme at this point of the film. For the most part, however, Dano's direction is invisible, relying far more on static painterly compositions than camera movement.

The acting, as you would expect, is universally superb. On paper, Jeanette and Warren Miller (a superb Bill Camp), an older man who becomes romantically interested in her, are very much the villains of the piece, but Mulligan and Camp's performances are so full of warmth and genuine emotion that you simply can't look at them as antagonists, and the film itself never judges them. Mulligan plays Jeanette as utterly weary, much older than her years, at times fragile, at times rock solid, both vulnerable and manipulative. Full of anger, she simply can't hold in her emotions any more. Unfortunately, in letting them out, she betrays Joe by forgetting he is only 14-years-old. When she starts drunkenly dancing with him at Miller's house, the scene is deeply uncomfortable, but Mulligan's performance is such that we don't condemn her, at least, not completely. She never allows the audience to lose sight of the fact that although she is behaving rather poorly, she is a prisoner, and is reacting against her restraints as best she can.

Of course, there are a few problems. Essentially a tale of marital angst, the narrative is not especially original - we've seen this story before, many times in fact, and for all the craft on display, Dano never really manages to say anything wholly new. Additionally, his measured direction is also too good in places - everything is so ordered, neat, and trim, that at times, the milieu doesn't seem lived-in, but more an abstract concept of what the period was like. Additionally, there are a few lines that sound great on paper, but which are just not the kind of things one says in real life. For example, Jeanette tells Joe, "I feel like I need to wake up, but I don't know what from, or what to". Later she says, "I wish I was dead. If you have a better plan for me, tell me. Maybe it'll be better than this". This kind of dialogue seems more interested in hitting thematic waypoints than developing character beats. Similarly, late in the film, Jerry says to Joe, "It's a wild life. Isn't it, son?" Proclaiming the film's title in this context doesn't even remotely work, and the line feels totally out of place, to the point of ripping you out of the narrative.

On the one hand, Wildlife is about how society was changing in 1960, and on the other, about how that change manifests itself within the Brinson family. Yes, it's another "death of the American dream" story in a long line of such films, but here, the focus is, for the most part, on character rather than theme, with Jeanette functioning in kind of a synecdochical manner; our specific entry point, she is the individual that facilitates an examination of the masses. And yes, Dano may take his eye off the ball a couple of times, with the odd bit of clunky dialogue, and a somewhat too picture-postcard perfection, but all in all, this is an excellent directorial debut.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":7}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26988,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.8},"contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Drama"],"datePublished":"2019-01-01","keywords":"1960s,unemployment,photography,infidelity,firefighter","trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1986312985","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg","description":"A boy witnesses his parents' marriage falling apart after his mother finds another man."},"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm4590837/","name":"Ed Oxenbould"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0350453/","name":"Jake Gyllenhaal"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1659547/","name":"Carey Mulligan"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0585931/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0564372/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0625497/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1443740/","name":"Zoe Kazan"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0285840/","name":"Richard Ford"}],"duration":"PT1H45M"}</script><metacontent="

When she starts drunkenly dancing with him at Miller's house, the scene is deeply uncomfortable, but Mulligan's performance is such that we don't condemn her, at least, not completely. She never allows the audience to lose sight of the fact that although she is behaving rather poorly, she is a prisoner, and is reacting against her restraints as best she can.

Of course, there are a few problems. Essentially a tale of marital angst, the narrative is not especially original - we've seen this story before, many times in fact, and for all the craft on display, Dano never really manages to say anything wholly new. Additionally, his measured direction is also too good in places - everything is so ordered, neat, and trim, that at times, the milieu doesn't seem lived-in, but more an abstract concept of what the period was like. Additionally, there are a few lines that sound great on paper, but which are just not the kind of things one says in real life. For example, Jeanette tells Joe, "I feel like I need to wake up, but I don't know what from, or what to". Later she says, "I wish I was dead. If you have a better plan for me, tell me. Maybe it'll be better than this". This kind of dialogue seems more interested in hitting thematic waypoints than developing character beats. Similarly, late in the film, Jerry says to Joe, "It's a wild life. Isn't it, son?" Proclaiming the film's title in this context doesn't even remotely work, and the line feels totally out of place, to the point of ripping you out of the narrative.

On the one hand, Wildlife is about how society was changing in 1960, and on the other, about how that change manifests itself within the Brinson family. Yes, it's another "death of the American dream" story in a long line of such films, but here, the focus is, for the most part, on character rather than theme, with Jeanette functioning in kind of a synecdochical manner; our specific entry point, she is the individual that facilitates an examination of the masses. And yes, Dano may take his eye off the ball a couple of times, with the odd bit of clunky dialogue, and a somewhat too picture-postcard perfection, but all in all, this is an excellent directorial debut.","reviewRating":"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":7,"aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26988,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.8,"contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Drama"],"datePublished":"2019-01-01","keywords":"1960s,unemployment,photography,infidelity,firefighter","trailer":"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1986312985","thumbnail":"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg","thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg","description":"A boy witnesses his parents' marriage falling apart after his mother finds another man.","actor":["@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm4590837/","name":"Ed Oxenbould","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0350453/","name":"Jake Gyllenhaal","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1659547/","name":"Carey Mulligan"],"director":["@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano"],"creator":["@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0585931/","@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0564372/","@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0625497/","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1443740/","name":"Zoe Kazan","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0285840/","name":"Richard Ford"],"duration":"PT1H45M"</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Mister Bob
Mister Bob
programme.desc: Mister Bob: Directed by Thomas Vincent. With Clovis Cornillac, Christophe Vandevelde, Dan Herzberg, Olivier Rabourdin. This film is based on the true character of Robert Denard (known as Bob Denard) in the 60's when he fights in Democratic Republic of Congo. As a mercenary, he defends President Mobutu who won his position after a putsch. Despite pressures from the French government who supports Mobutu's opponent Moïse Tshombé, Denard stays loyal to Mobutu until the very end when he unsterdands Mobutu wants him dead. Denard's only solution becomes to get rid of Mobutu, however the French governmet ends up changing side to support Mobutu. programme.title: Séjour dans les monts Fuchun
programme.desc: La famille Gu est réunie dans un grand restaurant la ville-district de Fuyang, où travaille l'un de ses membres pour célébrer les 70 ans de la matriarche du clan. Mère de quatre fils, qui pour certains ont également fondé des familles, elle retrouve avec joie ses enfants et ses petits enfants. Mais la soirée est marquée par un premier incident, mineur, une panne d'électricité, avant de s'achever inopinément sur une note plus inquiétante : la matriarche est victime d'un évanouissement. Les médecins qui s'occupent d'elle diagnostiquent alors un début de démence.

programme.title: A Bread Factory: Part One
A Bread Factory, Part 1 : ce qui nous unit
programme.desc: A Bread Factory: Part One: Directed by Patrick Wang. With Tyne Daly, Elisabeth Henry, James Marsters, Shershah Mizan. After 40 years of running their community arts space, The Bread Factory, Dorothea and Greta are suddenly fighting for survival when a celebrity couple--performance artists from China--come to Checkford and build an enormous complex down the street catapulting big changes in their small town." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt6884380/","name":"A Bread Factory: Part One","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMDBkNzI1ODAtNjAwOC00ODk1LTlhNmMtYTVlNjAxZjY3MTI4XkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyMjM0MTk0MA@@._V1_.jpg","description":"After 40 years of running their community arts space, The Bread Factory, Dorothea and Greta are suddenly fighting for survival when a celebrity couple--performance artists from China--come to Checkford and build an enormous complex d","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt6884380/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"westsideschl"},"dateCreated":"2019-12-26","inLanguage":"English","name":"Snooze 1","reviewBody":"A series of slightly connected vignettes encased in allusion, satire, parody, sarcasms, spoofing clichés concerning a small town arts theatre & school at risk of losing funding when a famous, out-of-town, group build a larger one down the street. programme.title: Président
Président
programme.desc: Président: Directed by Lionel Delplanque. With Albert Dupontel, Jérémie Renier, Claude Rich, Mélanie Doutey. Mathieu, a bright student, falls in love with Nahema, who happens to be the President of the Republic's daughter. The President, a loving but invading father, finally accepts him as his daughter's boyfriend, going as far as appointing Mathieu as one of his consultants. Working with the President, Mathieu will find out who he actually is." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt0478719/","name":"Président","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTMyNTQxNTA3M15BMl5BanBnXkFtZTcwMDY5MzY4Mg@@._V1_.jpg","description":"Mathieu, a bright student, falls in love with Nahema, who happens to be the President of the Republic's daughter. The President, a loving but invading father, finally accepts him as his daughter's boyfriend, going as far as appointin","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0478719/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"roxlerookie"},"dateCreated":"2006-09-20","inLanguage":"English","name":"A really good movie about the human dimension in French politics","reviewBody":"I'm French, I saw this one before its release in theaters in France. It is really, really very good. It gives a very good flavor of the politics world, uses and customs, men, women, and so on. You see how people handle power, how power ends up controlling them. At no moment it is a "left wing" or a "right wing" movie, but it really focuses on the human dimension of the people. It uses many historical details from former 5th republic presidents, such as Miterrand (left), Giscard (right), Chirac (current one, right), De Gaulle (right/center). Dupontel is really amazing considering the all different types of roles he can fit in. In Bernie, in Monique, in this one, he plays 3 totally different persons, but always very accurately and well. To sum up, this is worth seeing. The girl (president's daughter is really cute, though she is not the best actor in the movie). The dude (Mathieu) is doomed to be loved by girls, and it's true that he is nearly perfect.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":557,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.7},"genre":["Drama","Thriller"],"datePublished":"2006-09-20","keywords":"french president,female rear nudity","actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0243355/","name":"Albert Dupontel"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0753737/","name":"Jérémie Renier"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0723623/","name":"Claude Rich"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0217803/","name":"Lionel Delplanque"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0065548/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0079800/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0146460/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0217803/","name":"Lionel Delplanque"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1217275/","name":"Raphaël Meltz"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2409312/","name":"Agnès Caffin"}],"duration":"PT1H37M"}</script><metacontent="

The President, a loving but invading father, finally accepts him as his daughter's boyfriend, going as far as appointing Mathieu as one of his consultants. It is really, really very good. It gives a very good flavor of the politics world, uses and customs, men, women, and so on. You see how people handle power, how power ends up controlling them. At no moment it is a "left wing" or a "right wing" movie, but it really focuses on the human dimension of the people. It uses many historical details from former 5th republic presidents, such as Miterrand (left), Giscard (right), Chirac (current one, right), De Gaulle (right/center). Dupontel is really amazing considering the all different types of roles he can fit in. In Bernie, in Monique, in this one, he plays 3 totally different persons, but always very accurately and well. To sum up, this is worth seeing. The girl (president's daughter is really cute, though she is not the best actor in the movie). Set in a tropical resort, it follows the exploits of various guests and employees over the span of a week." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"TVSeries","url":"/title/tt13406094/","name":"The White Lotus","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOWY1YjY1MWUtYWY5Yi00YTM4LTkyM2UtMDQ3NmFiYTkyYjlkXkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyMDM2NDM2MQ@@._V1_.jpg","description":"Set in a tropical resort, it follows the exploits of various guests and employees over the span of a week.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt13406094/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"idospasjody"},"dateCreated":"2021-08-11","inLanguage":"English","name":"This is the BEST dark comedy in years","reviewBody":"This is a gem. The writing and acting is amazing. I can't wait for every Sunday evening. I wish I wouldn't have started it so I could binge watch the hole thing. There are parts that it takes a few seconds for your brain to process and then bang OMG laugh out loud funny. Rewind watch again funny. The story telling is masterful. Only thing wrong with this show is can't find anything to it's equal wile waiting for the next one to be released.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":10}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":27138,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.7},"contentRating":"TV-MA","genre":["Comedy","Drama"],"datePublished":"2021-07-11","keywords":"male explicit nudity,resort,full frontal male nudity,social satire,satire","actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0058864/","name":"Murray Bartlett"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0110168/","name":"Connie Britton"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0177639/","name":"Jennifer Coolidge"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0193472/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0925234/","name":"Mike White"}],"trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1544732697","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BYTRkZmMyYmMtNDNiYi00MDYyLTgyYTEtNmVhYjcwZTljZWRjXkEyXkFqcGdeQXZ3ZXNsZXk@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BYTRkZmMyYmMtNDNiYi00MDYyLTgyYTEtNmVhYjcwZTljZWRjXkEyXkFqcGdeQXZ3ZXNsZXk@._V1_.jpg","description":"Among the employees at The White Lotus are the fastidious resort manager Armond (Murray Bartlett), who, after a sudden trauma, begins a dramatic downward spiral - and the down-to-earth spa manager, Belinda (Natasha Rothwell) who gets taken on an emotional roller coaster ride by a needy guest. The vacationers include the Mossbacher family - Nicole (Connie Britton), a successful type-A exec, who can't help but treat her family like disobedient employees; her husband, Mark (Steve Zahn), dealing with both an embarrassing health crisis and a terminal inferiority complex; their teenaged son, Quinn (Fred Hechinger), a socially awkward gamer, experiencing the wonder of nature for the very first time; their daughter, Olivia (Sydney Sweeney), and her friend, Paula (Brittany O'Grady), sharp-tongued college sophomores who cast a sardonic eye on the lifestyles and belief systems of everyone around them. The handsome, entitled Shane Patton (Jake Lacy) is here with his beautiful bride, Rachel (Alexandra Daddario). Shane and Rachel are in the throes of young love, but as they get to know each other better in this new, intimate environment, clouds of doubt appear - and by the time Shane's intrusive mother, Kitty (Molly Shannon) surprises them with an unwelcome visit, their fairytale honeymoon has begun to unravel. And finally, there is Tanya McQuoid (Jennifer Coolidge), a wealthy, unstable woman, recovering from the death of her mother, traveling alone to the hotel, looking for love and in desperate need of a massage."}}</script><metacontent="

The vacationers include the Mossbacher family - Nicole (Connie Britton), a successful type-A exec, who can't help but treat her family like disobedient employees; her husband, Mark (Steve Zahn), dealing with both an embarrassing health crisis and a terminal inferiority complex; their teenaged son, Quinn (Fred Hechinger), a socially awkward gamer, experiencing the wonder of nature for the very first time; their daughter, Olivia (Sydney Sweeney), and her friend, Paula (Brittany O'Grady), sharp-tongued college sophomores who cast a sardonic eye on the lifestyles and belief systems of everyone around them. The vacationers include the Mossbacher family - Nicole (Connie Britton), a successful type-A exec, who can't help but treat her family like disobedient employees; her husband, Mark (Steve Zahn), dealing with both an embarrassing health crisis and a terminal inferiority complex; their teenaged son, Quinn (Fred Hechinger), a socially awkward gamer, experiencing the wonder of nature for the very first time; their daughter, Olivia (Sydney Sweeney), and her friend, Paula (Brittany O'Grady), sharp-tongued college sophomores who cast a sardonic eye on the lifestyles and belief systems of everyone around them. The handsome, entitled Shane Patton (Jake Lacy) is here with his beautiful bride, Rachel (Alexandra Daddario). Shane and Rachel are in the throes of young love, but as they get to know each other better in this new, intimate environment, clouds of doubt appear - and by the time Shane's intrusive mother, Kitty (Molly Shannon) surprises them with an unwelcome visit, their fairytale honeymoon has begun to unravel. And finally, there is Tanya McQuoid (Jennifer Coolidge), a wealthy, unstable woman, recovering from the death of her mother, traveling alone to the hotel, looking for love and in desperate need of a massage."}}</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Take Shelter
Take Shelter
programme.desc: Take Shelter: Directed by Jeff Nichols. With Michael Shannon, Jessica Chastain, Tova Stewart, Shea Whigham. Plagued by a series of apocalyptic visions, a young husband and father questions whether to shelter his family from a coming storm, or from himself." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt1675192/","name":"Take Shelter","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BNzgzODA5MTU3MF5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTcwODY4MDEwNg@@._V1_.jpg","description":"Plagued by a series of apocalyptic visions, a young husband and father questions whether to shelter his family from a coming storm, or from himself.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt1675192/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"JoshuaDysart"},"dateCreated":"2011-10-29","inLanguage":"English","name":"Essential Viewing for our Times","reviewBody":"I hear it so much now. Our national discourse is rich with portent. "It's going to get worse before it gets better", "Something horrible is coming, you'll see", "Soon there will be riots". I'm told these things at conventions and while talking to my neighbors and at breakfast with my mother's old friends. Now Jeff Nichols takes an exhausted phrase in storytelling, ("There's a storm coming") and crafts out of it the movie of the moment. A dark, symbolic mapping of the last five years of the middle-class American experience that's bursting at the mental and financial seams. I have yet to see a finer artistic expression of the current existential crises we face. Michael Shannon is the Noah of our hour, plagued with calamitous visions and barely bearing up under the weight of constant anxiety. In fact, the whole endeavor is buried in quiet distress and prescience. And when the movie finally finds the heart to redeem it's long suffering protagonist, it is through the worst of all possible outcomes. Essential viewing for our times.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":97151,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.4},"contentRating":"R","genre":["Drama","Sci-Fi","Thriller"],"datePublished":"2011-11-10","keywords":"schizophrenia,ambiguous ending,psychological,storm,storm shelter","trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Take Shelter","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi3746995481","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTc2MDkyODA4Nl5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwNjUwNTYyMzE@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTc2MDkyODA4Nl5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwNjUwNTYyMzE@._V1_.jpg","description":"Plagued by a series of apocalyptic visions, a young husband and father questions whether to shelter his family from a coming storm, or from himself. "},"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0788335/","name":"Michael Shannon"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1567113/","name":"Jessica Chastain"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0924154/","name":"Shea Whigham"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2158772/","name":"Jeff Nichols"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0109632/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0376329/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0307251/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2158772/","name":"Jeff Nichols"}],"duration":"PT2H1M"}</script><metacontent="

credits.actor: Bill Maher

programme.title: Le syndrome du surimi
programme.desc: Juliette Katzman est atteinte du syndrome du surimi : C'est le syndrome de Stockholm version addiction à une vie de galère. A défaut de manger du crabe, jouer Tchekhov, vivre une histoire d'amour et avoir son indépendance, Juliette est une célibataire qui se goinfre de surimi, fait le clown dans des gouters d'anniversaire et vit avec sa grand-mère. Mais une panne d'ascenseur va offrir à Juliette la possibilité de s'échapper de sa vie discount. Va-t-elle réussir à créer une romance avec son voisin, jouer le rôle de sa vie et enfin manger un vrai crabe appétissant ?

programme.title: Une affaire d'état
Une affaire d'État
programme.desc: Une affaire d'état: Directed by Eric Valette. With Rachida Brakni, André Dussollier, Thierry Frémont, Christine Boisson. A plane explodes above the Gulf of Guinea. An escort girl is murdered in a Parisian park. Thousands of miles separate these two events, and yet Nora Chahyd, believes there's a connection between them, much to his superiors chagrin. As Nora investigates, getting dangerously close to the powers that be, the murders and betrayals accumulate, and signs point to a state affair at the heart of it all." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt1282156/","name":"Une affaire d'état","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTQyMjMzMTY2N15BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMDE0MjcwMzE@._V1_.jpg","description":"A plane explodes above the Gulf of Guinea. programme.title: Une chance sur six
Une chance sur six
programme.desc: Une chance sur six: Directed by Jacques Malaterre. With Patrick Sébastien, Évelyne Dandry, Nicolas Van Beveren, Anne Sila. Gay antiques dealer and big-time gambler Hubert Vallon lives with mega-rich Patricia, who finds him entertaining. An arrangement which suits them both. But now, Hubert wants more freedom. He plots to murder Patricia and have a stranger accused in his place. Unfortunately for him, a determined police officer suspects him." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt7871130/","name":"Une chance sur six","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTM4Yjg0YzMtOTBkZS00MGRiLWE0ZjUtNWZhMDU1NjljYmI4XkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyMTAwMzM3NDI3._V1_.jpg","description":"Gay antiques dealer and big-time gambler Hubert Vallon lives with mega-rich Patricia, who finds him entertaining. An arrangement which suits them both. But now, Hubert wants more freedom. He plots to murder Patricia and have a strang","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt7871130/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"ulicknormanowen"},"dateCreated":"2021-01-10","inLanguage":"English","name":"Rien ne va plus.","reviewBody":"Plot :A smug gay gambler ,married to a rich woman ten years his senior , picks up men in a casino . The wife's maid suggest her lover he take photographs of the husband's "games " and blackmail him: the wealthy wife told him she would disinherit her spouse if he entertained his lovers in her home. But that night when the future blackmailer comes to spy on his partner's employer ,he makes his would be lover play an unexpected game which has nothing to do with sex : roulette russe .(hence the title:" one chance out of six " -of pulling through and getting 100,000 euros -).\n\nThis is a welcome return to the murder mystery a la Boileau -Narcejac ("les diaboliques","vertigo"), full of unexpected twists , "you shouldn't go by appearances " style ,and the suspense is sustained till the very end ,in spite of many implausibilities -but it's the rule of the game .Both the gay self-satisfied rich person and the hypocrit cop who goes to church every Sunday are unsympathetic characters,but it adds spice to the situations .A long-haired Patrick Sebastien ,an ex TV host, manages pretty well as the devilish manipulator.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":7}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":42,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.6},"genre":["Comedy","Crime","Drama"],"datePublished":"2018-01-17","actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0845323/","name":"Patrick Sébastien"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0199281/","name":"Évelyne Dandry"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm3016596/","name":"Nicolas Van Beveren"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0538977/","name":"Jacques Malaterre"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0097717/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0125554/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0124813/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm4603624/","name":"Stéphane Bondoux"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0845323/","name":"Patrick Sébastien"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0538977/","name":"Jacques Malaterre"}],"duration":"PT1H36M"}</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Ma mère, le crabe et moi
Ma mère, le crabe et moi
programme.desc: Ma mère, le crabe et moi: Directed by Yann Samuell. With Émilie Dequenne, Lorette Nyssen, Jérôme Robart, Miveck Packa. 14-year-old Tania starts to become aware that the boys at school are interested in her at the same time as she learns that her mother has breast cancer." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt8258538/","name":"Ma mère, le crabe et moi","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BNzg5NGRlZmYtM2I4Ny00N2U4LWJhNmEtNjlmNThmNGRkYjYzXkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyMTExNzIzNjg4._V1_.jpg","description":"14-year-old Tania starts to become aware that the boys at school are interested in her at the same time as she learns that her mother has breast cancer.","aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":41,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.1},"genre":["Comedy","Drama","Family"],"datePublished":"2019-02-13","actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0220183/","name":"Émilie Dequenne"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm10471552/","name":"Lorette Nyssen"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0730176/","name":"Jérôme Robart"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1367933/","name":"Yann Samuell"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0088363/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0125554/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0090290/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm10186172/","name":"Elise Benroubi"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm3029656/","name":"Victoria Musiedlak"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm6822874/","name":"Anne Percin"}],"duration":"PT1H33M"}</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Anomalisa
Anomalisa
programme.desc:
Anomalisa: Directed by Duke Johnson, Charlie Kaufman. With David Thewlis, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Tom Noonan. A man crippled by the mundanity of his life experiences something out of the ordinary." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt2401878/","name":"Anomalisa","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTkyMzI2MzQ1N15BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwNDg0MzQxNzE@._V1_.jpg","description":"A man crippled by the mundanity of his life experiences something out of the ordinary.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt2401878/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"ronakkotian"},"dateCreated":"2020-09-27","inLanguage":"English","name":"Technically impressive and incredibly humane","reviewBody":"Charlie Kaufman has always put together fantastic and thought-provoking movies so I naturally get excited before I'm about to watch one. Anomalisa is another fantastic addition to his body of work.

Anomalisa follows Michael, who is tired of the mundanity in his life but soon experiences something special after meeting a woman named Lisa.

Apart from Human Nature and Confessions of a Dangerous Mind, I have seen every Kaufman film and loved every single one of them. Anomalisa is yet another film where Kaufman studies the human psyche and it's one of the best looking animated films I've seen. Since Kaufman doesn't have experience with stop motion, Duke Johnson came to help and the stop motion animation is visually striking. Despite being small in scale, the world of Anomalisa feels incredibly real. There are some impressive long takes where we follow characters into different rooms. Considering the challenges of stop motion, doing a long take is incredibly difficult so I have to praise the hard work put in by the animators because on a technical level this film is phenomenal.

This film isn't just style over substance because Charlie Kaufman adds so much depth and purpose to the characters and scenarios. This is a film that is sure to resonate with a lot of people. As of right now, I cannot relate to it as much but a few years down the line I may really connect with its themes. I love how interpretive Anomalisa is. It's not just a film you forget after finishing it. I still find myself thinking about the ending and other details. The voice acting is really good. David Thewlis does a terrific job as Michael and Jennifer Jason Leigh is absolutely fantastic as Lisa.

Anomalisa is another fantastic Kaufman film that's not only technically impressive but also humane and relatable. It's sad to see a talented writer like him struggle to fund his movies. I really hope he continues to write and direct more films as there is no writer like Charlie Kaufman.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":69284,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.3},"contentRating":"R","genre":["Animation","Comedy","Drama"],"datePublished":"2016-03-11","keywords":"multiple characters voiced by same person,one night stand,stop motion animation,hotel room,sex in hotel room","trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Trailer #1","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi143831577","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjA5OTUzNDY1MV5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMDQ5MjkxNzE@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjA5OTUzNDY1MV5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMDQ5MjkxNzE@._V1_.jpg","description":"A man struggles with his inability to connect with other people.
"},"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000667/","name":"David Thewlis"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000492/","name":"Jennifer Jason Leigh"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0006888/","name":"Tom Noonan"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2122478/","name":"Duke Johnson"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0442109/","name":"Charlie Kaufman"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0390995/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0133023/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0295464/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0442109/","name":"Charlie Kaufman"}],"duration":"PT1H30M"}</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Wildlife
Wildlife : une saison ardente
programme.desc:
Wildlife: Directed by Paul Dano. With Ed Oxenbould, Jake Gyllenhaal, Carey Mulligan, Travis W Bruyer. A teenage boy must deal with his mother's complicated response after his father temporarily abandons them to take a menial and dangerous job." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt5929754/","name":"Wildlife","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOTNlZWY2ZGQtY2U1ZS00Mjc5LWExNjgtM2Q4YzQyYTlmNjZhXkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyODY3Nzc0OTk@._V1_.jpg","description":"A teenage boy must deal with his mother's complicated response after his father temporarily abandons them to take a menial and dangerous job.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt5929754/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Bertaut"},"dateCreated":"2018-11-16","inLanguage":"English","name":"Old-fashioned filmmaking with a progressive theme","reviewBody":"The directorial debut of actor Paul Dano, Wildlife is based on the 1990 novel by Richard Ford, and is written for the screen by Dano and his girlfriend Zoe Kazan. Looking at the implosion of a family from the perspective of a 14-year-old member of said family, the film is thematically similar to Revolutionary Road (2008) and Blue Valentine (2010), and aesthetically similar to the Texas scenes in The Tree of Life (2011) (the period detail drips off the screen, whilst the use of a child as the focaliser colours much of what's depicted). And although Wildlife is a piece of remarkably nostalgic filmmaking, at the same time, it tells somewhat of a progressive story, demonstrating the uncertainty with which second-wave feminism manifested itself at a grassroots level prior to really taking off in 1963. Although it's essentially a character study, the film also suggests the 1950s-style clean-cut, neatly trimmed, rigidly defined way of life, built around the perfect nuclear family wherein a wife must be subservient to her husband, is about to become a thing of the past.

Set in Great Falls, Montana in 1960, the film tells the story of the peripatetic Brinson family; father Jerry (Jake Gyllenhaal), mother Jeannette (Carey Mulligan), and 14-year-old son Joe (Ed Oxenbould). When Jerry loses his job and takes off in a misguided attempt to reaffirm his masculinity by fighting a forest fire, something is awoken in Jeanette, who, for the first time, allows herself to admit she has become deeply unhappy, and overnight, her behaviour changes dramatically, as she rebels against her domesticity. Determined to forge a new identity, she is adamant she won't become one of the "standing dead" (the term used for trees that survive a forest fire).

Importantly, the film is set three years prior to Betty Friedan's ground-breaking The Feminine Mystique (1963), which redefined the parameters of all gender-based topics, depicting a society in which women were no longer content to do their husband's bidding and raise children. Initially, Jeanette is depicted as a quintessential 1950s wife and mother, almost to the point of cliché; she cooks, cleans, washes the clothes, does the dishes, sees that Joe attend to his homework, and when Jerry loses his job, it is Jeanette who goes out looking for work for both of them. She knows that her (unspoken and unacknowledged) role in this patriarchal society is to hold the family together, but it's a role that is nothing like she thought it would be when she was younger. Although she and Jerry seem to love one another, or they certainly used to, she clearly feels trapped by her domestic situation.

That her transformation happens so quickly is the key point; when she goes to bed, she's a wife and mother, trapped in her domestic environment, but when she wakes the next morning, she realises that she has an opportunity to escape, perhaps the best opportunity she will ever get. This has been building up for years, but she has gotten so used to feeling lost that when she gets a chance to change things, she doesn't even recognise it as such, at least not at first. Once she does, however, Jeanette makes a conscious decision to stop performing the role delegated by men. As much of the female population of the western hemisphere would be asking over the next ten or so years, Jeanette wants to know, "is this all there is?" She wants more than simply getting through the day. In this sense, she recalls Nora Helmer from Henrik Ibsen's A Doll's House (1879), or any number of Tennessee Williams heroines - a woman who wakes up to find she has become deeply unhappy despite attaining everything she once wanted, and who sets out to do whatever it takes to alter her course.

That all is not well in the Brinson household is hinted at in the opening scene, where Jerry and Jeanette have a couple of inconsequential but noticeable disagreements over dinner (such as whether Joe should continue pursuing football). This scene establishes an assuredness and subtlety-of-hand that lasts for the entire film, with Dano's directorial work proving unexpectedly sophisticated. For example, something he does several times is have characters walk off-screen to speak, whilst keeping the camera trained on Joe as he tries to listen, with the dialogue barely perceptible from just off the edge of the frame. As well as being an excellent use of off-screen space, something you don't see too often, this technique ties us rigidly to Joe's POV early on, inculcating us into his worldview. Another very nice piece of direction is an early montage cutting between Jeanette riding her bike, Jerry driving the car, and Joe riding the bus, in which each character is facing a different direction, each in isolation from the other two. It's basic cinematic shorthand, showing instead of telling, but it's very well done. Equally impressive is the penultimate scene, where Dano uses the windows of the Brinson house to block the characters in such a way as to suggest both their inner emotions, and the prevailing theme at this point of the film. For the most part, however, Dano's direction is invisible, relying far more on static painterly compositions than camera movement.

The acting, as you would expect, is universally superb. On paper, Jeanette and Warren Miller (a superb Bill Camp), an older man who becomes romantically interested in her, are very much the villains of the piece, but Mulligan and Camp's performances are so full of warmth and genuine emotion that you simply can't look at them as antagonists, and the film itself never judges them. Mulligan plays Jeanette as utterly weary, much older than her years, at times fragile, at times rock solid, both vulnerable and manipulative. Full of anger, she simply can't hold in her emotions any more. Unfortunately, in letting them out, she betrays Joe by forgetting he is only 14-years-old. When she starts drunkenly dancing with him at Miller's house, the scene is deeply uncomfortable, but Mulligan's performance is such that we don't condemn her, at least, not completely. She never allows the audience to lose sight of the fact that although she is behaving rather poorly, she is a prisoner, and is reacting against her restraints as best she can.

Of course, there are a few problems. Essentially a tale of marital angst, the narrative is not especially original - we've seen this story before, many times in fact, and for all the craft on display, Dano never really manages to say anything wholly new. Additionally, his measured direction is also too good in places - everything is so ordered, neat, and trim, that at times, the milieu doesn't seem lived-in, but more an abstract concept of what the period was like. Additionally, there are a few lines that sound great on paper, but which are just not the kind of things one says in real life. For example, Jeanette tells Joe, "I feel like I need to wake up, but I don't know what from, or what to". Later she says, "I wish I was dead. If you have a better plan for me, tell me. Maybe it'll be better than this". This kind of dialogue seems more interested in hitting thematic waypoints than developing character beats. Similarly, late in the film, Jerry says to Joe, "It's a wild life. Isn't it, son?" Proclaiming the film's title in this context doesn't even remotely work, and the line feels totally out of place, to the point of ripping you out of the narrative.

On the one hand, Wildlife is about how society was changing in 1960, and on the other, about how that change manifests itself within the Brinson family. Yes, it's another "death of the American dream" story in a long line of such films, but here, the focus is, for the most part, on character rather than theme, with Jeanette functioning in kind of a synecdochical manner; our specific entry point, she is the individual that facilitates an examination of the masses. And yes, Dano may take his eye off the ball a couple of times, with the odd bit of clunky dialogue, and a somewhat too picture-postcard perfection, but all in all, this is an excellent directorial debut.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":7}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26988,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.8},"contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Drama"],"datePublished":"2019-01-01","keywords":"1960s,unemployment,photography,infidelity,firefighter","trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1986312985","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg","description":"A boy witnesses his parents' marriage falling apart after his mother finds another man."},"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm4590837/","name":"Ed Oxenbould"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0350453/","name":"Jake Gyllenhaal"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1659547/","name":"Carey Mulligan"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0585931/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0564372/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0625497/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1443740/","name":"Zoe Kazan"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0285840/","name":"Richard Ford"}],"duration":"PT1H45M"}</script><metacontent="

As much of the female population of the western hemisphere would be asking over the next ten or so years, Jeanette wants to know, "is this all there is?" She wants more than simply getting through the day. In this sense, she recalls Nora Helmer from Henrik Ibsen's A Doll's House (1879), or any number of Tennessee Williams heroines - a woman who wakes up to find she has become deeply unhappy despite attaining everything she once wanted, and who sets out to do whatever it takes to alter her course.

That all is not well in the Brinson household is hinted at in the opening scene, where Jerry and Jeanette have a couple of inconsequential but noticeable disagreements over dinner (such as whether Joe should continue pursuing football). This scene establishes an assuredness and subtlety-of-hand that lasts for the entire film, with Dano's directorial work proving unexpectedly sophisticated. For example, something he does several times is have characters walk off-screen to speak, whilst keeping the camera trained on Joe as he tries to listen, with the dialogue barely perceptible from just off the edge of the frame. As well as being an excellent use of off-screen space, something you don't see too often, this technique ties us rigidly to Joe's POV early on, inculcating us into his worldview. Another very nice piece of direction is an early montage cutting between Jeanette riding her bike, Jerry driving the car, and Joe riding the bus, in which each character is facing a different direction, each in isolation from the other two. It's basic cinematic shorthand, showing instead of telling, but it's very well done. Equally impressive is the penultimate scene, where Dano uses the windows of the Brinson house to block the characters in such a way as to suggest both their inner emotions, and the prevailing theme at this point of the film. For the most part, however, Dano's direction is invisible, relying far more on static painterly compositions than camera movement.

The acting, as you would expect, is universally superb. On paper, Jeanette and Warren Miller (a superb Bill Camp), an older man who becomes romantically interested in her, are very much the villains of the piece, but Mulligan and Camp's performances are so full of warmth and genuine emotion that you simply can't look at them as antagonists, and the film itself never judges them. Mulligan plays Jeanette as utterly weary, much older than her years, at times fragile, at times rock solid, both vulnerable and manipulative. Full of anger, she simply can't hold in her emotions any more. Unfortunately, in letting them out, she betrays Joe by forgetting he is only 14-years-old. When she starts drunkenly dancing with him at Miller's house, the scene is deeply uncomfortable, but Mulligan's performance is such that we don't condemn her, at least, not completely. She never allows the audience to lose sight of the fact that although she is behaving rather poorly, she is a prisoner, and is reacting against her restraints as best she can.

Of course, there are a few problems. Essentially a tale of marital angst, the narrative is not especially original - we've seen this story before, many times in fact, and for all the craft on display, Dano never really manages to say anything wholly new. Additionally, his measured direction is also too good in places - everything is so ordered, neat, and trim, that at times, the milieu doesn't seem lived-in, but more an abstract concept of what the period was like. Additionally, there are a few lines that sound great on paper, but which are just not the kind of things one says in real life. For example, Jeanette tells Joe, "I feel like I need to wake up, but I don't know what from, or what to". Later she says, "I wish I was dead. If you have a better plan for me, tell me. Maybe it'll be better than this". This kind of dialogue seems more interested in hitting thematic waypoints than developing character beats. Similarly, late in the film, Jerry says to Joe, "It's a wild life. Isn't it, son?" Proclaiming the film's title in this context doesn't even remotely work, and the line feels totally out of place, to the point of ripping you out of the narrative.

On the one hand, Wildlife is about how society was changing in 1960, and on the other, about how that change manifests itself within the Brinson family. Yes, it's another "death of the American dream" story in a long line of such films, but here, the focus is, for the most part, on character rather than theme, with Jeanette functioning in kind of a synecdochical manner; our specific entry point, she is the individual that facilitates an examination of the masses. And yes, Dano may take his eye off the ball a couple of times, with the odd bit of clunky dialogue, and a somewhat too picture-postcard perfection, but all in all, this is an excellent directorial debut.","reviewRating":"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":7,"aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26988,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.8,"contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Drama"],"datePublished":"2019-01-01","keywords":"1960s,unemployment,photography,infidelity,firefighter","trailer":"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1986312985","thumbnail":"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg","thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTAzZTk4MDQtZWIyZS00MDMyLTkyNTgtMjU0MDA0YWRlN2I4XkEyXkFqcGdeQW1yb3NzZXI@._V1_.jpg","description":"A boy witnesses his parents' marriage falling apart after his mother finds another man.","actor":["@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm4590837/","name":"Ed Oxenbould","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0350453/","name":"Jake Gyllenhaal","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1659547/","name":"Carey Mulligan"],"director":["@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano"],"creator":["@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0585931/","@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0564372/","@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0625497/","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0200452/","name":"Paul Dano","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1443740/","name":"Zoe Kazan","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0285840/","name":"Richard Ford"],"duration":"PT1H45M"</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Recount
Recomptage
programme.desc: Recount: Directed by Jay Roach. With Kevin Spacey, Bob Balaban, Ed Begley Jr., Laura Dern. A chronicle of the weeks after the 2000 U.S. Presidential election, and the subsequent recounts in Florida." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt1000771/","name":"Recount","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BNDMwNDYzOTg4NF5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTcwNzEwNzE3MQ@@._V1_.jpg","description":"A chronicle of the weeks after the 2000 U.S. Presidential election, and the subsequent recounts in Florida.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt1000771/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Benedict_Cumberbatch"},"dateCreated":"2008-05-25","inLanguage":"English","name":""I just wanna know who actually won this f***ing election!"","reviewBody":"Jay Roach (the "Austin Power" series, "Meet the Parents") doesn't seem the right director for a political-driven movie about one of the most controversial elections ever, but he did a good job in charge of this well-executed HBO production. "Recount" features solid performances all around, particularly Kevin Spacey as Ron Klain (Al Gore's recount point man) and Tom Wilkinson as James Baker (Bush's top recount strategist); Laura Dern seemed to have fun playing the ridiculously clueless (and potentially malevolent) Katherine Harris (Florida's Secretary of State), the woman who stopped the recount. The movie works for being wittily unbiased (Spacey's outburst scene: "You know what's funny? I don't even know if I like Al Gore... I just wanna know who actually won this f***ing election!" is pivotal, and his last conversation with Wilkinson/Baker is also a great point) and informative for those who have short-term memory (or were too young 8 years ago). We all know how it's gonna end, and the movie doesn't have the pretension of answering eternal questions like "Who really won the election and would have Al Gore been a better president?" We'll most likely never know the first, and can just wonder about the second. For better or worse, things would've been different had Bush lost, that's for sure. It might not be a solace, but that's the only truth we have, and the makers of "Recount" seem to be aware of that. 7.5/10."},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":12711,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.4},"contentRating":"TV-MA","genre":["Drama","History"],"datePublished":"2008-05-25","keywords":"election,presidential election,shady,state name in title,american politics","actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000228/","name":"Kevin Spacey"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000837/","name":"Bob Balaban"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0001459/","name":"Denis Leary"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0005366/","name":"Jay Roach"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0005861/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0114242/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0038270/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0834960/","name":"Danny Strong"}],"duration":"PT1H56M"}</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Midnight in Paris
Minuit à Paris
programme.desc:
Midnight in Paris: Directed by Woody Allen. With Owen Wilson, Rachel McAdams, Kurt Fuller, Mimi Kennedy. While on a trip to Paris with his fiancée's family, a nostalgic screenwriter finds himself mysteriously going back to the 1920s every day at midnight." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt1605783/","name":"Midnight in Paris","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTM4NjY1MDQwMl5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTcwNTI3Njg3NA@@._V1_.jpg","description":"While on a trip to Paris with his fiancée's family, a nostalgic screenwriter finds himself mysteriously going back to the 1920s every day at midnight.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt1605783/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"jdesando"},"dateCreated":"2011-06-03","inLanguage":"English","name":""We'll always have Paris."","reviewBody":""Paris, France is exciting and peaceful." Gertrude Stein

Welcome to the world of Woody Allen as he has always loved it: nostalgic, romantic, imperfect, and full of hope. Midnight in Paris is one of his finest treatises on the lure and delusions of the past: Like Zelig it depicts other times, like Purple Rose of Cairo it uses magic realism to deal squarely with the present. Allen has another of his surrogates, this time Gil (Owen Wilson),who virtually experiences the past (the twenties) while dealing with the troublesome present.

Gil, engaged to marry Inez (Rachel McAdams), is with her and her parents on business in Paris where he hopes to work on his novel while he is still a successful Hollywood writer. Although she is a materialist who would like him to become wealthy to enjoy the life his parents are used to, he dreams of escaping the hack work of LA and living in the City of Lights for inspiration, just as his idols Fitzgerald and Hemingway did in the roaring twenties.

Well, the twenties roar back to him as he experiences their friendship and the mentoring of Gertrude Stein, among just a few of the many expatriate luminaries he meets through the magic of nostalgia. Just one of the Allen signature touches that make him the equal of great European directors such as Rohmer and Godard is opening the film with music that reflects the allure of the twenties, the romance of Paris, and his abiding love for this city: "Si Tu Vois Ma Mere" by Sidney Bechet combines jazz, the clarinet, the twenties, and Allen with a romantic nostalgia.

Owen Wilson catches the halting diffidence of the typical Allen persona without slavishly imitating him. Yet whatever little duplication Wilson employs endears as he sweetly visits his heroes, falls in love, and comes to terms with his writer's voice and his mismatched engagement. But that engagement is the troublesome present; the past offers the chance to experience history on a human level that only someone who writes for now and reveres the past can do. 

The magic and the realism, both requiring hard work from the protagonist, lead to surprising understanding of human nature, the delusion of nostalgia and Paris, and hope for a present that brings love and inspiration.

"For all we know, Paris might be the hottest place in the universe." (Gil)

It's been at least a decade since I have enjoyed an Allen movie this much."},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":402679,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.7},"contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Comedy","Fantasy","Romance"],"datePublished":"2011-05-11","keywords":"time travel romance,1920s,nostalgia,reference to auguste rodin,art history","trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Midnight in Paris","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi853581081","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjNkOTFmZDctNWZmZS00MDhhLWJmZDctODkwNjcyYzkzNTg3XkEyXkFqcGdeQXRzdGFzaWVr._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjNkOTFmZDctNWZmZS00MDhhLWJmZDctODkwNjcyYzkzNTg3XkEyXkFqcGdeQXRzdGFzaWVr._V1_.jpg","description":"On vacation in Paris, a married man who is somewhat of a killjoy slowly falls in love ... with the city itself."},"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0005562/","name":"Owen Wilson"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1046097/","name":"Rachel McAdams"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000870/","name":"Kathy Bates"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000095/","name":"Woody Allen"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0002375/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0224201/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0044777/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000095/","name":"Woody Allen"}],"duration":"PT1H34M"}</script><metacontent="

While on a trip to Paris with his fiancée's family, a nostalgic screenwriter finds himself mysteriously going back to the 1920s every day at midnight." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt1605783/","name":"Midnight in Paris","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTM4NjY1MDQwMl5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTcwNTI3Njg3NA@@._V1_.jpg","description":"While on a trip to Paris with his fiancée's family, a nostalgic screenwriter finds himself mysteriously going back to the 1920s every day at midnight.","review":"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt1605783/","author":"@type":"Person","name":"jdesando","dateCreated":"2011-06-03","inLanguage":"English","name":""We'll always have Paris."","reviewBody":""Paris, France is exciting and peaceful." Gertrude Stein

Welcome to the world of Woody Allen as he has always loved it: nostalgic, romantic, imperfect, and full of hope. Midnight in Paris is one of his finest treatises on the lure and delusions of the past: Like Zelig it depicts other times, like Purple Rose of Cairo it uses magic realism to deal squarely with the present. Allen has another of his surrogates, this time Gil (Owen Wilson),who virtually experiences the past (the twenties) while dealing with the troublesome present.

Gil, engaged to marry Inez (Rachel McAdams), is with her and her parents on business in Paris where he hopes to work on his novel while he is still a successful Hollywood writer. Although she is a materialist who would like him to become wealthy to enjoy the life his parents are used to, he dreams of escaping the hack work of LA and living in the City of Lights for inspiration, just as his idols Fitzgerald and Hemingway did in the roaring twenties.

Well, the twenties roar back to him as he experiences their friendship and the mentoring of Gertrude Stein, among just a few of the many expatriate luminaries he meets through the magic of nostalgia. Just one of the Allen signature touches that make him the equal of great European directors such as Rohmer and Godard is opening the film with music that reflects the allure of the twenties, the romance of Paris, and his abiding love for this city: "Si Tu Vois Ma Mere" by Sidney Bechet combines jazz, the clarinet, the twenties, and Allen with a romantic nostalgia.

Owen Wilson catches the halting diffidence of the typical Allen persona without slavishly imitating him. Yet whatever little duplication Wilson employs endears as he sweetly visits his heroes, falls in love, and comes to terms with his writer's voice and his mismatched engagement. But that engagement is the troublesome present; the past offers the chance to experience history on a human level that only someone who writes for now and reveres the past can do. 

The magic and the realism, both requiring hard work from the protagonist, lead to surprising understanding of human nature, the delusion of nostalgia and Paris, and hope for a present that brings love and inspiration.

"For all we know, Paris might be the hottest place in the universe." (Gil)

It's been at least a decade since I have enjoyed an Allen movie this much.","aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":402679,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.7,"contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Comedy","Fantasy","Romance"],"datePublished":"2011-05-11","keywords":"time travel romance,1920s,nostalgia,reference to auguste rodin,art history","trailer":"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Midnight in Paris","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi853581081","thumbnail":"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjNkOTFmZDctNWZmZS00MDhhLWJmZDctODkwNjcyYzkzNTg3XkEyXkFqcGdeQXRzdGFzaWVr._V1_.jpg","thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjNkOTFmZDctNWZmZS00MDhhLWJmZDctODkwNjcyYzkzNTg3XkEyXkFqcGdeQXRzdGFzaWVr._V1_.jpg","description":"On vacation in Paris, a married man who is somewhat of a killjoy slowly falls in love ... with the city itself.","actor":["@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0005562/","name":"Owen Wilson","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1046097/","name":"Rachel McAdams","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000870/","name":"Kathy Bates"],"director":["@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000095/","name":"Woody Allen"],"creator":["@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0002375/","@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0224201/","@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0044777/","@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000095/","name":"Woody Allen"],"duration":"PT1H34M"</script><metacontent="

programme.title: L'angle mort
L'angle mort
programme.desc:
L'angle mort: Directed by Patrick-Mario Bernard, Pierre Trividic. With Jean-Christophe Folly, Isabelle Carré, Golshifteh Farahani, Sami Ameziane. Dominick Brassan has the power to turn invisible, but he keeps it a shameful secret. Then, when his ability to control his gift gets out of hand, his life, friendships and relationships will be forever turned inside out." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt9412514/","name":"L'angle mort","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZDE1ZGZiMWQtNzIzMC00OTE2LWJlYzMtNGM2YjRlY2MxMDAyXkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyODU4MzMxNDg@._V1_.jpg","description":"Dominick Brassan has the power to turn invisible, but he keeps it a shameful secret. Then, when his ability to control his gift gets out of hand, his life, friendships and relationships will be forever turned inside out.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt9412514/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"ulicknormanowen"},"dateCreated":"2020-04-23","inLanguage":"English","name":"Stick with HG Welles!","reviewBody":"An update of HG Wells' classic the invisible man" ? How tempting! And no need for scientific research ; our hero's gift is innate .Some scientists told Welles that an invisible man had to be blind ,and the writer was aware of it .For the 21st century invisible man , not only he 's not , but he does not wear any clothes when he uses his "gift" : he always loiters in the nude when he spies on his fellow men ; the warnings on the imdb page are thoroughly true: full frontal male nudity ,and one wonders what it is trying to prove .

The story starts under favourable auspices :the prologue,notably , with the baby who disappears is a smart way to introduce the hero .The odd suicides wave in the subway gives an eerie feel to the movie (Welles' hero committed a murder too and intended to commit more ) ,as do the strange TV broadcasts .Besides,Dominick , the invisible man, is black , it could have been a brilliant anti-racist fable.The love affair with a blind musician is another good idea ,much more interesting than the first girlfriend who naively thinks that New-York is only waiting for her. But promises remain on hold.

It's the directors (they are two!) ' wish,but it 's Welles' reality. "Masterful!" claims a critic on a poster which is pure wishful thinking: what's definitely lacking is a firm screenplay ; Dominick is afraid to lose his powers ,but one never feels his fear :as far as suspense is concerned ,my "hitckocometer" points sullenly towards zero.Humor is totally absent ,even in the scene in the toilets .All the characters ,Dominick's mom and dad (of course divorced,but dad comes back to sing a little tune (of course, in English!) for his dying wife ), nurse sister , friendly boss, are cardboard ,and one wonders why one should take an interest in their life .","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":4}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":247,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.7},"genre":["Drama"],"datePublished":"2019-10-16","keywords":"male programme.desc:
Miss You Already: Directed by Catherine Hardwicke. With Drew Barrymore, Shola Adewusi, Toni Collette, Grace Schneider. The friendship between two life-long girlfriends is put to the test when one starts a family and the other falls ill." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt2245003/","name":"Miss You Already","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjQzNDE1OTM5M15BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMTQwMTAwNzE@._V1_.jpg","description":"The friendship between two life-long girlfriends is put to the test when one starts a family and the other falls ill.","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt2245003/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"nicole-43868"},"dateCreated":"2016-01-27","inLanguage":"English","name":"Heart-felt performance","reviewBody":"The story line and acting was absolutely amazing. I was engaged in the movie from the beginning to the credits. The story line was realistic, coherent and relatable to the struggles some suffer. This movie brings awareness to life issues that are hard to imagine, yet you can feel these in this movie. 

All actors did an outstanding job playing their characters. The setting was fantastic as well. 

I do not want to spoil the movie so I won't say more details! 

I am very picky with the movies I watch and all I can say is that it is worth watching!!!","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":10}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":18162,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.8},"contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Comedy","Drama","Romance"],"datePublished":"2015-09-25","keywords":"title directed by female,title written by female,friendship,cancer,friend","trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi287355673","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTQ0NDA5OTA5Nl5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMTgyNTA3NjE@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTQ0NDA5OTA5Nl5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMTgyNTA3NjE@._V1_.jpg","description":"The friendship between two life-long girlfriends is put to the test when one starts a family and the other falls ill."},"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000106/","name":"Drew Barrymore"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0001057/","name":"Toni Collette"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1002641/","name":"Dominic Cooper"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0362566/","name":"Catherine Hardwicke"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0104822/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0477751/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0235242/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0052218/","name":"Morwenna Banks"}],"duration":"PT1H52M"}</script><metacontent="
